title: Stashing Changes üì¶
ques:
You have uncommitted changes but need to switch branches urgently.

Save your current changes to a temporary storage area (stash) so your working directory is clean.
explanation: **`git stash`** records the current state of the working directory and the index, then reverts to a clean working directory.

title: Applying Stashed Changes üì§
ques:
You want to bring back the changes you stashed but **keep** them in the stash list for later use as well.

Apply the latest stash.
explanation: **`git stash apply`** restores the most recently stashed changes but leaves them in the stash stack.

title: Popping Stashed Changes üçæ
ques:
You want to restore the latest stash and **remove** it from the stash list immediately.

Pop the stash.
explanation: **`git stash pop`** restores the changes and drops them from the stack in one go.

title: Cherry-Picking üçí
ques:
You need a specific commit `abc1234` from the `dev` branch to be applied to your current `main` branch, without merging the whole branch.

**Cherry-pick** this commit.
explanation: **`git cherry-pick <commit>`** applies the changes introduced by some existing commit to your current branch as a new commit.

title: Selective Staging ü§è
ques:
You have many changes in a file but only want to stage **some** of them (hunks).

Start the interactive staging mode.
explanation: **`git add -p`** (patch) allows you to interactively choose which hunks of code to stage.
